title: Tyson to Close Lexington, NE Beef Plant; 3,200 Jobs Affected
summary: Tyson Foods announced the permanent closure of its Lexington, Nebraska beef processing facility, impacting about 3,200 workers and citing a historically low U.S. cattle herd and the need to "right-size" its beef business; the closure is expected to significantly affect the local economy and regional cattle supply dynamics.[3][5]

title: Tyson Foods Reports Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2025 Results
summary: Tyson Foods reported fiscal 2025 results including $54.441 billion in sales and GAAP operating income of $1.098 billion, with management noting year-over-year growth in sales, adjusted operating income and adjusted EPS and declaring an increased quarterly dividend payable December 15, 2025.[1] The company provided outlooks for fiscal 2026, including anticipated chicken adjusted operating income of $1,250–$1,500 million and commentary on expected domestic protein production trends.[1]

title: Federal Court Orders 30-Year Remediation, Assigns Penalties in Oklahoma v. Tyson Foods
summary: A U.S. District Court issued a judgment on December 19, 2025 finding Tyson Foods and other integrators liable in the decades-long Illinois River watershed case, ordering a comprehensive 30-year remediation plan, new limits on poultry litter application, and assessing civil penalties including $160,000 against Tyson Foods.[5] The ruling prompted responses from state officials and industry groups and has immediate operational implications for poultry contracts in the watershed.[5][6]

title: Tyson Says It Will Not Renew Oklahoma Poultry Contracts Unless Lawsuit Terms Change
summary: In response to the federal ruling and related litigation, Tyson announced it would begin the process of allowing poultry contracts in the Illinois River watershed to expire and said it would not enter new Oklahoma poultry contracts unless the terms of the pollution lawsuit were eased or resolved on acceptable terms.[4][2] State and local leaders warned of economic impacts to rural communities if integrators and growers disengage from the region.[2][3]

title: UK Imposes Sanctions on PJSC Russneft and Other Major Russian Oil Companies
summary: The UK government announced 24 new sanctions on December 18, 2025, targeting four major Russian oil companies including PJSC Russneft, PJSC Tatneft, LLC Rusneftegaz Group, and LLC NNK-Oil, which collectively generate over $20 billion in revenue. These measures aim to disrupt Russia's war economy by targeting firms fueling exports amid plummeting oil revenues. The sanctions hit entities supporting the Russian energy sector and military supply chains.

title: Honeywell Announces Agreement with Wabash Valley Resources for Carbon Capture Technology Deployment
summary: Honeywell has partnered with Wabash Valley Resources to integrate carbon capture technology at a modernized facility in West Terre Haute, Indiana, producing low-carbon hydrogen and 500,000 metric tons of anhydrous ammonia fertilizer annually by 2028. The project aims to reduce reliance on imported fertilizers for the Corn Belt and lower emissions. Engineering is handled by SAMSUNG E&A.

title: Wabash Valley Resources Secures $1.5 Billion DOE Loan Guarantee for Ammonia Production Facility
summary: The U.S. Department of Energy has provided a conditional $1.5 billion loan commitment to Wabash Valley Resources for repurposing an idled gasifier in West Terre Haute, Indiana, to produce 500,000 metric tons of anhydrous ammonia yearly with carbon capture of 1.6 million metric tons of CO2. The project, part of a $2.4 billion investment including private funds, will create over 1,100 jobs and strengthen domestic fertilizer supply chains. It is expected to be operational by 2028.

title: Baker Botts Advises DOE on $1.5 Billion Loan Closing for Wabash Valley Resources Fertilizer Plant
summary: Baker Botts advised the DOE's Loan Programs Office on the closing of a $1.5 billion loan to Wabash Valley Resources under the Energy Dominance Financing Program. The financing supports restarting a plant idled since 2016 to produce 500,000 metric tons of anhydrous ammonia annually using coal and petcoke, with carbon capture technology. This strengthens supply chains for the eastern Corn Belt.

title: Wayne-Sanderson Farms Involved in $1.73M Charitable Impact from 2025 Sanderson Farms Championship

title: Newcastle Disease Outbreaks Devastate Poland's Poultry Industry, Impacting Wipasz Operations
summary: Since January 2025, Poland has reported over 30 outbreaks of Newcastle disease, leading to the loss of approximately 3.5 million birds and causing significant operational disruptions for major processors like Wipasz. Facilities in Podlaskie province experienced supply chain breakdowns and temporary production halts, contributing to financial instability. The government mandated vaccinations in April 2025, but the virus continues to spread despite enhanced biosecurity measures.

title: Şenpiliç Gıda Sanayi A.Ş. Competition Investigation Fined 357 Million TRY
summary: Şenpiliç Gıda Sanayi A.Ş., süt ve süt ürünleri sektöründe Rekabet Kurulu tarafından Article 4 ihlali nedeniyle 357,687,454.48 TRY idari para cezasına çarptırıldı. Bu, yem-süt baskı şeması ile ham süt satan hayvancılık çiftliklerine yönelik soruşturmanın tamamlanması sonucu gerçekleşti. title: Amick Farms Agrees to $6.25 Million Settlement in Poultry Wage-Fixing Class Action Lawsuit
summary: Amick Farms is part of settlements totaling $180 million by nine poultry processors in a long-running antitrust lawsuit alleging wage suppression since 2009. This follows prior settlements by other major players like Tyson Foods and Perdue Farms.

title: Thai Commerce Minister Secures 30,000 Tonne Cassava Pellets Export Deal with ARASCO
summary: Commerce Minister Suphajee Suthumpun negotiated a deal for Thailand to export 30,000 tonnes of cassava pellets to Saudi Arabia's ARASCO, following a prior 20,000 tonne shipment. Discussions also covered potential cooperation on animal feed ingredients, broken-milled rice, Napier grass, and processed poultry products to support ARASCO's poultry industry expansion and Saudi food security. ARASCO expressed interest in further orders, possibly up to 100,000 tonnes next year.[1][2]

title: Arvesta Opens New Plant Protein Facility in Mettet, Belgium

title: Atria Plc Establishes New Share-Based Incentive Plans for Key Employees
summary: Atria's Board of Directors resolved on December 17, 2025 to establish a new Performance Share Plan and Restricted Share Unit Plan for key employees, along with launching a second performance period for the Bridge Plan covering 2026. title: Atria Invests EUR 23 Million in Meat Product Production at Sköllersta Plant
summary: Atria announced an investment of EUR 23 million in meat product production at its Sköllersta facility in Sweden, with work beginning in December 2025 and scheduled completion in Q1 2027. This modernization investment is part of the company's broader capital expenditure program to enhance production capacity and efficiency.

title: Aviva to Resume Share Buybacks at Higher Level in 2026
summary: Aviva confirmed plans to resume share buybacks in March 2026 at an increased level to reflect the 14% higher share count following the Direct Line acquisition. The company reaffirmed commitment to mid-single-digit growth in dividend cash cost beyond 2025.

title: Avara Foods Records £55 Million Loss Following Major Restructuring
summary: Avara Foods, a major UK poultry supplier, reported a pre-tax loss of £55 million for the year ending May 31, 2024, following significant restructuring that included closing two processing facilities and opening a new added-value processing site. Sales declined from £1.5 billion in 2023 to £1.3 billion in 2024, with £11.5 million in one-off restructuring costs contributing to the loss.
